Q19: Good discussion of the topic and relevance to personal experience. / Avoid reading from slides. It would be necessary to include structure in your handout and correlate it with function. / Appropriate discussion of treatment options. / In the slide show including graphs to illustrate the point would be very helpful.

Overall the handout was written well and the topic was interesting. Some of the major highlights of the studies were presented and attempt was made to make eye contact with the audience. The presentation can be improved by avoiding reading directly from the slides. In discussion of mechanism of action it would be helpful to briefly show biochemical schemes and structure of the compounds. In these studies understanding of the purity of the compounds is necessary. Spending more time on each slide, including graphics, and pondering on the controversy to be discussed would further improve the presentation.

Q4: Presentation style was very good.  The pace was fast, but I think that was appropriate and kept attendees involved.  The only concern that I had was the need to look away from the audience to read the slides on the screen.  This may have been caused by the pointer not working, but the presenter chose to stand in front of the podium which meant that he couldn't see the computer screen.  He didn't need to look at notes much, but it would have been better for him to stand where he could see the computer screen and turn away from the audience.
Q6: Good.  I only saw one typo.
Q10: Not a lot of statistical analysis because of presentation of a meta-analysis, but what was presented was clearly explained.
Q12: Conclusions were appropriate based on the data presented.
Q14: Handled questions well.  There were not a lot of questions.
Q16: Seemed to have an excellent overall knowledge base.

Q6: Could have made more use of graphics to tell his story.  Virtually every slide was text.
Q12: recommendations were consistent with the data and appropriate
Q14: could have done a better job answering questions.  Some answers were superficial

Q4: Very timid at the beginning but did a nice job of adjusting her presentation style during the presentation
Q6: too much data on the slides.  No graphics and some spelling errors
Q8: Very through coverage of the literature.  Some question whether there is a true controversy regarding this topic and the drug presented
Q10: great job of presenting the data although the amount of data presented was overwhelming
Q12: great job of discussing statins and their clinical relevance.  Again not sure there is much controversy with regard to the use of pitavastatin
Q14: managed the question answer session extremely well
Q16: great job of presenting the data and engaging the audience
Q19: great job for a P3 seminar.  I would like to see more confidence in the presentation next year and consideration of the level of controversy associated with the topic.

Q4: Was clearly nervous during his presentation.  There were times when he just read from the slide and went on to the next slide.
Q6: Materials and slides were clear and concise.  No problems with any of the materials.
Q8: Good discussion of the background (disease state) and interest in topic.  Need to work on the transitions from slide to slide.
Q10: Overall good job.  There was a little confusion on the audience's part regarding the second study and the active placebo.  Should have taken a little time to explain more thoroughly the study design for both studies.
Q12: Probably the best section of the seminar.  Could have spent a little more time talking about adverse events associated with MDMA and how this is not a problem is this study setting.  Also, should have been prepared to discuss addiction potential as it pertains to use in this setting.
Q14: Not many questions were asked by the audience.  To encourage questions be prepared to ask the audience a question or two to make sure they are comprehending the material.  Also puts the audience at ease and encourages questions.
Q16: Despite a little anxiety it was clear the Paul had a pretty good understanding of the topic beyond what was presented.
Q19: Reasonable first seminar.  Work on being better prepared and rehearse with slides.  This will go a long way to making you more relaxed and comfortable in front of the audience.

Q4: this was the weakest part of the seminar.  Amy was very nervous and it negatively impacted her seminar.  At times she seemed confused and not sure what she wanted to say.  Other times her voice trailed off and never quite finished what she was saying.  While there was no microphone available, it would not have mattered.  Need to project your voice and be more affirmative in your presentation.
Q6: No issues with slides or handouts - very easy to read.  Like that the HAMD was included in the handout materials.
Q8: Not sure she ever stated her interest in the topic.  Controversy was well identified.  Background info (disease and treatment) was appropriate as this is a topic all should be well versed on.  Transitions from slide to slide was a major weakness.  As stated already, seemed a bit confused about what to say on some slides and left the audience hanging in places.
Q10: there was some confusion from the audience regarding how small sample size was a limitation given that the study was powered and achieved statistical significance. While her identification of small sample size as a limitation is accurate, need to explain to the audience why this is the case.
Q12: conclusions were supported by the evidence presented.  Would like to have seen some discussion regarding the fact that fish oil seemed to be more effective than an SSRI at treating depression.  This seems a bit hard to believe.  Not much in the way of discussion of the role of the pharmacist other than to say she would recommend fish oil to patients on antidepressants.  Would like to have seen a bit more discussion here.
Q14: Did not get much in the way of questions and did nothing to encourage the audience to interact.
Q16: there was little in the way of discussion that convinced the audience that she had knowledge beyond what was presented.  Did little to nothing to put these results in any context.
Q19: the most important thing to work on for your next seminar is to rehearse your presentation in advance until you are very comfortable with it.  I would recommend writing your entire  seminar out so that you have a script for each slide to read.  You will know that you are ready to present when you can go thru the presentation and not read from your script.  This will go a long way to make you more comfortable presenting.

Q6: Slides and handouts were instructive, easy to understand and w/o errors.
Q12: Reasonable conclusions. / Good explanation of the pharmacists role.
Q16: Demonstrated broad knowledge of the subject and analytical thinking.

Q4: Good presentation; some slides were just read.
Q8: Enthusiastically presented; good explanation of the topic at a level suitable for the audience.
Q12: Conclusions appropriate; pharmacist's role explained well.
Q14: Good answers based on extensive studies.
Q16: As the speaker mentioned discussion with Dr. Oderda were very helpful.
Q19: Very good presentation; clearly explained the topic, results and conclusions.

Q4: I thought your presentation style was excellent. Great style, pace, tone. No notes. You were out from behind the podium and seemed very comfortable.
Q6: I thought your slides were nice. You had some really nice pictures to break up the words.
Q8: I thought this was a great topic, and you did a great job describing your interest. just be careful. It would not be hard for someone to figure out who that patient was (90-year-old-female, admitted to Riverton Hosp last summer for AAD who coded and died). If you had a family member in the audience, you could be looking at a HIPAA violation. Patient identifiers extend beyond names / I thought you did a nice job setting up the controversy. /  / Overall, your transitions between slides were really nice.
Q10: I thought you did a nice job with the studies. I still think the meta-analysis was really poorly done (by the authors). This can be tought to present!
Q12: I'm not sure the studies were strong enough to really draw conclusions from. I really liked your overview of the common products.
Q14: We probably gave you some tough questions, and you handled them with poise.
Q16: Again, I think you had tough studies. Don't be afraid to draw a different conclusion.

Q4: You had a great tone, pace, style. You were able to mix in comedy, yet maintain professionalism. It made the presentation enjoyable.
Q6: I thought your slides were easy to read. i love that your habdout tracks with your slides and that you referred the audience to specific page numbers for further info.
Q8: You did a great job setting up the ratioale and walking the audience through the background. You did a great job with your interest in the topic as well. /  / One are for improvement would be slide to slide transitions. You tended to use "so." You had a couple of really nice ones though ("I'd like to take a minute to talk about multimodal..."
Q10: I thought you did a nice job critiquing the studies. Only point was that small sample size may have given better safety profile than what we would see.
Q12: I thought you did a good job separating yuor conclusion from the authors' conclusions.
Q16: I could tell you did your research. I thought you  really tried to analyze the data.
Q19: I think you did a good job overall. Work on transiitions, never apologize for a slide that is hard to read.

Q4: Presentation style was confident and relaxed with good pace and eye contact.  Suggestion for next seminar: try moving out from behind the podium.
Q6: Instructional materials were very good.  I didn't notice any typos or misspelled words.  None of the data were plotted, so there weren't any graphs to orient the audience to, though Paul did a good job of highlighting the data in complex tables that he wished to discuss.  Citation and referencing was okay, though for next seminar I suggest mentioning to the audience that the bibliography given in the handout can be used to identify complete references for citations given in the slides.
Q8: All essential content was covered and background information was adequate for understanding the clinical studies.  The controversy was well defined and I particularly liked how it asked how dapagliflozin fits into present T2DM therapies and whether it's needed.  Objectives were okay, but could be more measurable.  Transitions were good.
Q10: Great job with presenting clinical studies.  Although your first study was weak in the statistics department, your second study was much better.  For your next seminar, try finding two studies that are adequately powered.
Q12: Conclusions and practice recommendations were well founded in the data presented.  Pharmacist role was thoughtful, though you didn't return to whether dapagliflozin has a role in T2DM therapy.
Q14: Good Q & A session.  I thought you gave thoughtful answers to my questions.  For next seminar, try a quiz or case study at the start of your presentation to encourage audience interaction.
Q16: Comprehensive knowledge base, though I don't recall you discussing clinical vs. statistical significance during the actual seminar.  For next seminar, try to anticipate the most likely questions before your seminar and prepare a few extra slides to answer them in case someone asks.

Q14: could work a bit more on engaging the audience
Q19: an overall excellent seminar; with more experiene and practice, you should be able to move about a bit more an engage the audience

Q4: Fairly quick pace initiatally, eventually settled into a more moderate pace. Keith, you were looking behind you at your slides quite a bit. Think about how you can arrange yourself and computer to avoid having to do this in the future. Good confidence and enthusiasm!
Q6: Would have liked to see page numbers on handouts. Many slides did not have citations! Consider use of abbreviated citations for future seminars. Some slides were a little wordy, next time think about how to streamline slides.
Q8: Good review of scores, would have liked to see more to help with introduction. Objectives should reflect all content provided, need objectives related to efficacy and safety. I dislike question slides - think about other ways to transition, ask the audience for feedback, and take a mental break.
Q10: Would have liked to have heard more about adverse effects profiles of meds and pros/cons of using dex compared to other treatment options. This would have helped give us a context and be able to make better conclusions.
Q12: Conclusions were specific and good impact of pharmacist section, applicable for practice.
Q14: Good job with some tough questions. Nice that you felt confident admitting when you did not know the answer, that's ok.
Q16: Would have liked more differentiation between author's conclusions and your conclusions, focus on what you take away as key points from study and how it pertains to your controversy.
Q19: Keith, overall great first seminar. You are enthusiastic, professional, and good clinical knowledge so excellent building blocks for next seminar. Things to work on for next time include: providing more context for discussion (more info about AE, cost comparison, etc. between drugs), fewer words on slides, and improved transitions.

Q4: I would echo the comments of your students - confidence is very important! Pace was a little slow at times, especially at times when you seemed nervous or flustered. I would encourage you next time to practice in the room that you will do your presentation. That way you can feel more comfortable with things like advancing the slides and where you want to position yourself in the room.
Q6: Numerous misspellings and typose, practice practice practice with other folks to help you catch these before your seminar.  Consider using more abbreviated citations next time. Consider using more charts/graphs next time to help you avoid too many words on slides. For example, an image to demonstrate the mechanism of action of statins.
Q8: Great introduction and interest in the topic, appreciated the personal story and highlighting the importance of CVD. I would have liked more introduction initiatially to the controversy - what is the potential role for pitivastatin? Is it meant to be a safer option or have less side effects? How are they advertising it? Definitely needed a dose comparison chart in background to help us understand intensity of pitavastatin and interpret doses in studies presented, this was a major weakeness to your presentation and inhibited your ability to critically evaluate the studies presented as well.
Q10: Would have liked to see more discussion about the limitations of the outcomes selected in the trials - not CV events but LDL reduction - especially in the context of the new lipid guidelines. Also, would have been helpful to discuss more in context of other primary literature of statin benefit or safety/adverse effects.
Q12: Tell us why you selected the trials that you did to present. You did a good job trying to pick statin comparison trials (vs. just placebo controlled) but help us understand why the data is poor or the wrong outcomes were selected.
Q14: You received some tough questions, although it made you nervous you answered professionally and thoughtfully and did well with this section. Be confident in your knowledge!
Q16: As previously mentioned, would have liked to see better understanding of context for presentation with knowledge of other statin therapies and benefits.
Q19: Stacey, overall a good first seminar presentation and a good topic selected. Things to keep working on for next seminar: have a good context for literature discussed by understanding previous literature/practice in the area and practice practice practice with other individuals to improve flow, catch errors/typos, and improve confidence! If you mentor doesn't meet with you in person to work on these together and have you give a practice presentation, pick a different mentor next time that will give you more feedback along the way.

Q4: Little bit fast delivery, pause more at the questions. / Depending on audience (like job interview), be less casual (avoid leaning on podium). / Overall excellent.
Q6: Good citing of figure sources.  Could use more chemical structures :-) although you did show one.
Q8: Good discussion of diabetes even though the class that it was too in-depth. The "current place in therapy" was a little small text wise and dark. Good discussion of treatment modalities.
Q10: Good discussion of limitations, such as lack of statistics, medication change in placebo.
Q12: Spend more time on controversy.  Excellent question answering.
